abstract.p: Using a sample of 8,790 firm‐years between 1993 and 1998, I examine investment policies of firms in Japanese industrial groups relative to independent firms. Unlike independent firms, there is little evidence that group firms' investment is sensitive to ex ante proxies of growth opportunities, and for the most tightly linked firms in the industrial group, there is a negative relation between industryQand industry‐adjusted investment. The difference in the investment pattern for group firms relative to independent firms is directly related to lower excess values for group firms. These findings are consistent with industrial groups decreasing investment efficiency.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Prior studies on internal capital markets in U.S. conglomerates arrived at three broad but controversial conclusions. First, internal capital markets appear to be active in allocating resources across business units. Second, this allocation seems inefficient, in that capital is not always allocated to the business units with the most profitable investment opportunities. Third, this apparent misallocation in capital is associated with a reduction in firm value. Diversified firms invest differently than single‐segment firms and trade at a discount relative to single‐segment firms. Moreover, the discount is associated with the extent of misallocation.1

This study builds on the previous literature by studying internal capital markets within Japanese industrial groups. Japanese industrial groups, calledkeiretsu,have interlocking share ownerships and are hypothesized to function like conglomerates. Although studies find less efficient investment associated with internal capital markets in conglomerates, some authors argue that the corporate governance structure of an industrial group is more effective than the conglomerate structure. This study complements prior work on investment patterns in U.S. conglomerates and other industrial groups but also goes beyond prior work by investigating investment patterns for types of firms within the industrial group and linking their investment policies to value.

This study aims to expand our understanding of industrial groups and internal capital markets by answering two important questions. First, is there evidence that Japanese industrial groups utilize their internal capital markets to reallocate capital analogously to conglomerates? Second, if so, does this reallocation appear to increase or decrease investment efficiency? Japan provides both a large sample of firms affiliated with industrial groups and a large sample of firms independent of industrial groups, thus creating a natural setting for this investigation.

Using a sample of 8,790 firm‐years between 1993 and 1998, I examine the investment policies of firms in Japanese industrial groups relative to independent firms. The evidence suggests that industrial groups in Japan actively reallocate capital, they are associated with less efficient investment patterns among their members, and the less efficient investment patterns are concentrated in the most tightly linked firms in the industrial group. Moreover, the investment patterns of firms in industrial groups are directly related to value loss.

Previous evidence on the effectiveness capital allocation in industrial groups is limited and ambiguous. Some evidence suggests that industrial groups provide more effective capital allocation in markets with less developed capital markets, as industrial groups can create an internal capital market as a substitute for external capital markets.2However, this study provides evidence consistent with the view that any potential benefits of the group structure in improving capital allocation do not extend to countries with developed capital markets.

Specifically, investment for firms in both horizontal and vertical groups is positively related to their own cash flow as well as the cash flows of the other firms in their respective keiretsus. This evidence is consistent with active capital reallocation among member firms. There is little evidence that the investment of keiretsu firms is sensitive to ex ante proxies of growth opportunities. In contrast, the investment of independent firms is positively correlated with ex ante proxies for growth opportunities.

For firms that are the central members of the group, as defined by being either deeply entrenched in the group3or a member of the group's president's assembly, investment is higher than that of their independent firm peers in low‐Qindustries and investment is lower than that of their independent firm peers in high‐Qindustries. The difference in the investment pattern for group firms relative to independent firms is directly related to lower excess values for group firms.4

The paper is organized as follows. Section II discusses the current theoretical and empirical evidence on internal capital markets and the keiretsu. Section III describes the sample and reports descriptive statistics. Section IV reports the multivariate results. Section V discusses the results, and Section VI concludes.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Structure of the Keiretsu
sec.p: Japanese industrial groups come in two forms. Horizontal keiretsus operate in a diverse set of industries and are centered on a main bank. There are eight horizontal keiretsus that each had an average of 86 firms during the sample period. The vertical keiretsus are more focused along a value chain within an industry. These keiretsus are typically centered on a major industrial firm(s) rather than a bank. The number of identified vertical keiretsus varies somewhat over the sample period. As of 1998, there were 35 vertical keiretsus, each of which had an average of seven firms.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Capital Reallocation within the Keiretsu
sec.p: Jensen and Meckling (1976), Myers and Majluf (1984), and Jensen (1986) provide the theoretical foundation for the way in which an external capital market can allocate resources to negative net‐present‐value projects and fail to invest in some positive net‐present‐value projects. Subsequent theoretical papers develop agency explanations for why internal capital markets can distribute capital in a more or less efficient manner than external capital markets. These papers show how the additional layer of control from headquarters to division can either reduce the total cost of agency problems and information asymmetries, as in Stein (1997), or exacerbate the cost, as in Scharfstein and Stein (2000) and Rajan et al. (2000).

The Japanese keiretsu have important differences from U.S. conglomerates in their ability to dictate investment policy. Foremost, the Japanese keiretsu has no official headquarters that can allocate capital in the manner as a headquarters in a conglomerate. Once a decision is made on capital allocation, a conglomerate can allocate resources in the form of budgets to division managers. In industrial groups, it is less clear who makes the resource‐allocation decision and how the decision is carried out once made.

In addition to not having a formal internal mechanism for dictating group policies, the external market for corporate control is not active for group firms in Japan. Cross‐equity holdings are extensive among members of an industrial group, which makes it unlikely that an outsider can successfully mount a hostile takeover. Takeover activity is generally limited to agreed‐upon mergers with the approval of the group (Kester1991).

However, despite not having a formal chief executive officer, means do exist to coordinate group activities. The horizontal groups do have the shacho‐kai (president's assembly) comprising representatives from the major firms in the keiretsu. These presidential assemblies of the keiretsus meet regularly, but the meetings are shrouded in secrecy. To prevent any unauthorized written record of the meeting, some groups do not even allow the members of the presidential assembly to take notes. Supposedly, operational strategies are not discussed so as not to violate the Anti‐Monopoly Law. However, it is widely believed that operational strategies are the primary focus of these meetings (Miyashita and Russell,1994).

There is no legal mechanism of enforcement for the decisions made by the presidential assembly. However, not only are voting rights and shared board members associated with cross‐shareholding but also a moral obligation to abide by the decisions made by the president's assembly. Berglof and Perotti (1994) argue that the enforcement mechanism lies in the group's collective ability to remove poorly performing managers. They claim that, since Japanese managers tend to stay with their company for their entire careers, building up firm‐specific skills, the threat of removal is both credible and effective.

Unlike a conglomerate, firms in industrial groups also have the external market to provide monitoring. Despite the lack of an active market for corporate control, the external capital market, arguably, provides incentives to improve the effectiveness of capital allocations in industrial groups relative to capital allocations in the conglomerate form. Kester (1991) states: “In a sense, the Japanese corporate governance system can be viewed to secure the best of two worlds. By tying themselves to one another in groups, yet eschewing outright ownership and control, Japanese corporations have been able to exploit some of the high‐powered incentives of the market that derive from independent ownership of assets, while relying on selective intervention by key equity owners to adapt contracts to new circumstances as needed.”

The extent of financial interdependence between members of the keiretsu allows for many ways to transfer investment capital among member firms, through the coordinated efforts of group members. The depth of financial interaction within industrial groups goes beyond private equity placements. Groups use a blend of contracts including equity, product relationships that include heavy use of trade credit, and other debt contracts.5

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Empirical Evidence
sec.p: There is some empirical evidence on investment patterns in industrial groups. Khanna and Palepu (2000) find evidence that capital allocation improves with increasing levels of diversity within Indian industrial groups. They argue that, in countries with less‐developed capital markets, firms can improve the efficiency of capital allocation by forming industrial groups. Industrial groups can create internal capital markets that can substitute for the lack of a developed external capital market.

Shin and Park (1999) and Perotti and Gelfer (2001) investigate investment patterns in industrial groups in Korea and Russia, respectively. Both studies provide evidence that industrial groups actively reallocate capital. Shin and Park find that firms in industrial groups in Korea have a positive relation between investment and their market‐to‐book ratio and independent firms do not. But group firms also invest at higher levels than independent firms, regardless of the investment opportunities of the industry, and group firms in Korea have relatively poor growth opportunities. Perotti and Gelfer provide evidence that investment by firms in bank‐centered industrial groups in Russia is more sensitive to growth opportunities than independent Russian firms.

The evidence is mixed on the effect of group membership on firm value in Japan. Lins and Servaes (1999) study whether there is a diversification discount for conglomerates in Japan. They find that the diversification discount in Japan occurs only for conglomerates that are members of a keiretsu. Wu, Sercu, and Chen (2000) find evidence of value loss for large keiretsu firms. Dewenter, Novaes, and Pettway (2001) study initial returns of IPOs and conclude that information problems are more severe for group firms. These problems can make possible opportunistic behavior against minority shareholders.

Other evidence that tends to support the view that keiretsus increase firm value includes Hoshi, Kashyap, and Scharfstein (1991). This study shows that keiretsu firms appear to have lower capital constraints than independent Japanese firms. The authors argue that this is value increasing and not evidence of overinvestment. Ferris, Kumar, and Sarin (1995) present evidence that agency problems are less pervasive in keiretsu firms than independent firms. This evidence implies that keiretsu firms have a more‐efficient investment policy, since investment efficiency and agency problems presumably are inversely related.
Credible arguments are made for why industrial groups might either increase or decrease the efficiency of capital allocation. Ultimately, this is an empirical question that this study addresses.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Description of the Sample
sec.p: The sample includes all Japanese firms from 1993 to 1998 that are listed on Worldscope and have all the necessary data. All financial data used in this study come from Worldscope. To fulfill the requirement for 1 year of lagged data, all data points are required to have 2 consecutive years of data. The sample excludes firms in the financial and service industries, SIC 6000–9999, and utilities, 4900–4999. However, all tests reported have also been conducted including firms in the financial and service industries as well as utilities and the results are substantively the same.

I categorize the sample firms by their membership in industrial groups or as independent. Membership in an industrial group is not always obvious to outside observers. Group membership is based on networks of equity and debt holders, banking relationships, shared board members, and product relationships. Dodwell Consulting/Brown and Company's6biannual listing of the membership of all Japanese industrial groups provides the data. Dodwell/Brown has tracked keiretsu membership in Japan since 1972 and has been used by previous financial economists as a reliable source of keiretsu affiliations.7

Some firms are members of more than one keiretsu. Dodwell/Brown's listing includes a measure for how deeply entrenched the firm is within each industrial group. Dodwell/Brown looks at the degree of cross‐ownership and historical relationships to assign the degree of entrenchment for a firm in an industrial group. It then assigns an entrenchment rating of 1 to 4. Based on the measure of entrenchment, each firm with dual membership in keiretsus is identified as to which keiretsu is their primary membership. The tests I report here include only primary memberships. The results are substantively the same whether I include or exclude secondary memberships. The final sample is 8,790 firm years.8

Using this measure, I find that, over the sample period, vertical firms are the most valuable. Horizontal firms have lower excess values before the natural log and an insignificantly larger natural log of excess values. Two measures of investment are used. First, I use total asset growth, because it captures all investment activities of the firm, whether they are expansion into new lines of business, expansion of the current lines of business, or the purchase of an existing business. More important, investment in current assets such as inventory and accounts receivable is captured in asset growth, which allows for a more complete picture of how industrial groups allocate capital. Asset growth for independent firms and horizontal group members is very similar. Vertical firms have significantly higher levels of asset growth.

The second measure of investment focuses only on changes in plant, property, and equipment (ΔPPE). Worldscope has data on capital expenditures for 3,659 of the 8,790 firm‐years in the sample. Since it constitutes a minority of the sample, I do not use this measure to avoid imposing a selection bias on the sample. Plant, property, and equipment and depreciation data are available for 5,180 out of the 8,790 firms in the sample. These proxies lessen any potential selection bias relative to using capital expenditures. Change in PPE for yearnis calculated as follows:

The descriptive results for change in PPE follow the same pattern as asset growth. Independent firms and horizontal group members are very similar, and vertical firms increase their PPE at a significantly higher rate.

EBITDA/TA, the firm's earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization divided by book assets, is used as a measure of the firm's operating cash flow. Operating cash flow for vertical group members' is significantly higher than for independent or horizontal group members.

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: Empirical Tests
sec.p: To investigate the differences in investment patterns of group firms relative to their independent firm counterparts, I first test whether available capital and growth opportunities of other firms in an industrial group influence investment in a member firm. Second, I compare the determinants of investment for group and independent firms. Finally, I test the level of group and independent firm industry‐adjusted investment relative to an ex ante measure of industry growth opportunities.

A significantly positive coefficient for Other EBITDA/TA suggests that capital available from other firms in the industrial group influences the investment levels for a group firm, which is evidence consistent with capital reallocation. A negative coefficient for OtherQis consistent with an efficient reallocation of capital, in that firms in the industrial group with higher values forQget priority for investment capital.

Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA), denominated by the book value of total assets, is included as a measure of internally generated investment capital within a firm. However, depreciation data in Worldscope is missing for some Japanese firms. Therefore, to check the robustness of the results, I also conducted the tests for the full sample using EBIT rather than EBITDA. These unreported results are substantively the same.

Chevalier (2000) provides evidence that using a median industry estimate of Tobin'sQas a proxy for a firm's growth opportunities can produce spurious results, because it measures growth opportunities with error. Unfortunately, industry proxies are the only market‐based measures available to estimate growth opportunities in conglomerates, since divisions of conglomerates are not publicly traded.9In this study, this issue can be avoided, because a member of an industrial group is a separate firm having its own market value.10

On the other hand, assuming efficient markets, the market value of a firm reflects any market perceived inefficiency in a firm's anticipated investment policy. Thus,Qcould be a biased proxy for available growth opportunities. Since it is not clear which method is most appropriate to test the robustness of the results, I include separate regressions that utilize both a median industry estimation and a firm‐level estimation of firm growth opportunities. Median industryQis defined as the firmQfor the median firm in the narrowest SIC level that includes at least five firms. If five firms are not available, the two‐digit SIC level is used.11Finally, each regression also includes size and firm‐level fixed effects.

The results intable 3indicate that cash flow is an important determinant of group firms' investment as well as the cash flow from the other members in the group. Both the EBITDA/TA and Other EBITDA/TA are significant in all models for asset growth. The results are less consistent for ΔPPE. The coefficients for Other EBITDA/TA show evidence of the presence of active internal capital markets. In all four models shown intable 3, the investment of horizontal group members is positively related to the cash flow of the other firms in the keiretsu. This result is true using either the broad definition of investment, asset growth, or the more narrow definition, ΔPPE. For vertical group members, cash flows from the rest of the group are positively correlated with asset growth but not for ΔPPE.

In panel A oftable 3, the results suggest that for every $1 increase in their EBITDA, a horizontal group member increases its assets between $0.74 and $0.77. Conversely, a $1 increase in cash flow from another group member is associated with additional investment of approximately $0.03, based on the coefficients and adjusting for the average size of a horizontal group.12These numbers suggest that own cash flow influences asset growth 23 to 24 times more than the same increase in other cash flow. This is compared to the 3 to 8 times, own relative to other cash flow, ratio as shown by Shin and Stulz (1998) in U.S. conglomerates. The small effect for industrial groups is not surprising, considering the size of the groups.

Another way to understand the economic significance of the coefficient is to ask if, on average, each group firm, other than the firm in question, increases its EBITDA by $1, how much does a horizontal group member increase its total assets? Based on the first two models of panel A oftable 3, the answer ranges from $1.15 to $1.17 as represented by the coefficients for Other EBITDA/TA.

These findings are consistent with Shin and Stulz's (1998) evidence of active internal capital markets in U.S. conglomerates, Shin and Park's (1999) evidence of active internal capital markets in Korean industrial groups, and Perotti and Gelfer's (2001) evidence that the internal capital markets of Russian industrial groups are active.

The coefficients for the proxies ofQare insignificant in all models for horizontal group members. Vertical group members have a significantly positive coefficient forQfor one proxy with asset growth as the dependent variable. This evidence suggests that group members' growth opportunities do not significantly influence their level of investment. If internal capital is less costly than external capital and internal capital markets are active and efficient, investment will be positively related to the firm's growth opportunities and negatively related to the growth opportunities of other firms in the industrial group. In the models intable 3, the coefficients for group firms are mixed on this prediction.

The difference in coefficients between these two subsets (1.127 relative to 0.295) is significant at the 1% confidence level.

For vertical group members, some of the coefficients lose their significance for the subsets intable 4as compared to the full set intable 3. However, the coefficients are similar in magnitude. If size is included in the regressions in panel A, the results are very similar and the coefficients generally have greater precision. These results are unreported.

Second, I ask if the determinants of investment differ for firms in industries with good growth opportunities relative to firms in industries with relatively poor growth opportunities. I divide the sample into firms in industries in which theQfor the median firm in the industry is higher (lower) than the medianQfor the sample, by year. Panel B oftable 4reports the results. The high‐Qsubset for horizontal groups has a positive relation withQand a negative relation with the growth opportunities from the rest of the group. This evidence appears consistent with an efficient investment policy. Conversely, investment for the low‐Qsubset of horizontal firms has a significant and negative coefficient forQand positive coefficient for theQof the rest of the group. Moreover, the low‐Qsubset has an EBITDA/TA coefficient over twice as large as the high‐Qsubset. This result suggests that the evidence of inefficient investment for horizontal group members is mainly attributable to the low‐Qsubset.

Investment for vertical group members in the high‐Qsubset has a positive relation withQand is not related to cash flows from the rest of their respective groups. Conversely, investment for the low‐Qsubset is not related toQand is positively related to cash flows from the rest of their group. It appears that vertical groups follow a similar pattern as horizontal groups in that investment appears to be less efficient among firms in industries that have below the median growth opportunities.

Market‐to‐book is an estimation of the marginal Tobin'sqcalculated in the same manner as used by Shin and Stulz (1998). Estimates of Tobin'sq= (Market value of equity + Book value of total assets − Book value of equity)/Book value of assets. This provides an estimate of averageQ, which is used as an estimate of the marginalQ. Whited (2001) provides a contrary viewpoint on the applicability of this measure.

The correlations between EBITDA/TA and Other EBITDA/TA for horizontal (vertical) groups are 0.089 (0.507). The correlations between firmQand median industryQfor horizontal (vertical) groups are 0.485 (0.235).

The size of the coefficients intable 5indicate that investment levels for group firms are influenced more by cash flow, while investment levels for independent firms are influenced more by growth opportunities. Using either estimate of growth opportunities, the coefficients for EBITDA/TA of both horizontal and vertical firms are over twice those of independent firms. Conversely, the coefficients for both proxies ofQare over three times larger for independent firms relative to horizontal group members.

I compared the coefficients for the OLS models using pairedt‐tests. These tests are not reported. For independent firms relative to horizontal group members, I compared the coefficients for models A and C and models B and D. The coefficients for EBITDA/TA are significantly lower for independent firms than for horizontal group members withp‐values of less than 1%. The coefficients for both proxies forQare significantly higher for independent firms than for horizontal group members at the 1% confidence level. Moreover, the coefficients for the proxies for growth opportunities for horizontal group members are either only significantly different from zero at the 5% confidence level, using a firm‐level estimate ofQ,or are not significantly different from zero at any conventional significance level.

When I compared the results of the determinants of investment, as defined by asset growth for independent firms relative to vertical group members, I obtained similar results. The comparisons of cash flow sensitivity from models A and B relative to E and F show that vertical group members have significantly larger coefficients withp‐values of less than 1%. The comparisons of coefficients forQfor independent firms relative to vertical group members are ambiguous. When I compare the coefficients for median industryQ,thep‐value shows that the coefficient for independent firms is significantly larger than for vertical group members at the 1% confidence level, but there is virtually no difference in the coefficients in firmQ.

The significant differences in coefficients discussed in this section are robust to the inclusion or exclusion of the other cash flow and otherQvariables, as shown intable 3. The differences are also robust to using the full data set utilizing EBIT rather than EBITDA. These results are not reported.

Panel B oftable 5uses change in PPE as the dependent variable. The comparisons of coefficients between independent firms relative to horizontal group members and vertical group members for EBITDA/TA and estimates forQare consistent with the results in panel A but less significant. The coefficients for EBITDA/TA are higher for horizontal and vertical group members than for independent firms. Conversely, the coefficients forQare higher for independent firms than for the members of horizontal or vertical groups. However, the differences are not significant at conventional levels for either EBITDA/TA or the estimates forQ.

The comparisons of coefficients for the models that use asset growth as the dependent variable are consistent with the hypothesis that group firms have less‐efficient investment policies than independent firms. The higher level of sensitivity to operating cash flow and a lower level of sensitivity for growth opportunities for group members do not appear to be consistent with efficient capital transfers between firms in the industrial groups.

The coefficients for operating cash flow and proxies forQare inconsistent with the evidence presented by Hoshi et al. (1991), who show that an independent Japanese firm's investment level is affected more by liquidity than by their keiretsu member counterparts. The samples in this paper and that of Hoshi et al. are different. Hoshi et al. define independent firms as those firms not in one of the largest six horizontal groups. Thus, in their study, these authors classified as independent a portion of the firms listed in this paper as horizontal, all of the vertical group members, and all of the independent firms. Their sample comprises 121 group firms and 24 independent firms from 1977 to 1982. In contrast, Hayashi (2000) finds that the coefficients for measures of liquidity are not significantly different for independent firms than for group firms.

sec.title: Do Industrial Groups Increase Investment Efficiency?

The dependent variable is industry‐adjusted investment, so that we can observe whether the firms tend to allocate more capital to industries with more‐valuable growth opportunities.

An efficient reallocation of capital within an internal capital market allows firms to mitigate both over‐ and underinvestment, as discussed earlier. A positive coefficient for median industryQsuggests that the subset of firms allocates relatively more capital to high‐growth industries and relatively less capital to low‐growth industries than the average firm in the entire sample. Thus, presumably, a positive coefficient forQis consistent with a more‐efficient investment policy.

The table lists separately the core members and the members of the president's assembly in horizontal groups. I define core members as those that have a Dodwell/Brown entrenchment rating of 4. As discussed in Section II, the members of a president's assembly provide a central decision‐making role within a horizontal keiretsu. These firms should have more power in the capital allocation decisions in the group. Virtually all core members are also members of the president's assembly. Of the horizontal group sample, 19% are classified as core members and 29% are members of the presidential assembly.

Panel A oftable 6shows that, although horizontal group members as a whole have a insignificant relation between the industryQand adjusted investment, the relation is significantly negative for firms that are either core members or members of the president's assembly. For horizontal group members, the allocation of capital appears to be worse for the firms that wield the most power in their respective industrial groups. These firms appear to invest in low‐Qindustries at higher levels than their independent firm peers and invest in high‐Qindustries at lower levels than their independent firm peers. Conversely, investment for independent firms is positively related to the quality of the firm's industry. This result is consistent with the findings intables 3,4, and5, which suggest that horizontal group members, as a whole, have investment patterns that are insensitive to proxies ofQ,as compared to independent firms that have a significantly positive relation betweenQand their investment. This result does not appear to apply to vertical group members, because the coefficient forQis insignificant for all vertical group members as it is for their core members.

Scharfstein (1998) finds that high‐Qsegments in U.S. conglomerates invest less than their pure play peers, but in low‐Qsegments, the reverse is true. The evidence of investment patterns from the presidential assembly members of horizontal industrial groups, as shown intable 6, is consistent with the investment patterns of U.S. conglomerates documented by Scharfstein.

Panel B investigates whether size is the true determinant of investment efficiency. Group firms are larger and the core members and members of the presidential assembly are almost exclusively above the median firm size. Thus, the results in panel A may reflect that large firms have a less‐efficient investment policy. Panel B divides the firms into above and below median firm size in the same manner as in panel A oftable 4. The results suggest that large firms do not drive the results in panel A oftable 6. It appears that the large independent firms have a more‐efficient investment policy relative to smaller independent firms, as shown by the significantly positive coefficient for median industryQ. Horizontal group members have an insignificant coefficient for the industryQfor all three subsets shown: large, large not presidential assembly members, and small. No subset has a significant and positive coefficient. Size does not appear to explain the significant and negative coefficient for core and presidential assembly members of horizontal groups. Additionally, presidential assembly firms are not clustered in high‐ or low‐growth opportunity industries. The presidential assembly has 248 firm‐years above and 268 firm‐years below the median industryQ.

Panel C reports the results of the tests using the industry‐adjusted change in PPE. Panel C provides consistent but less‐significant evidence of inefficient investment by core and president's assembly members of horizontal groups. The coefficients for the industryQare larger for independent firms relative toQfor horizontal group members. The evidence is more convincing for both core horizontal group members and members of the president's assembly. The core and presidential assembly members have a coefficient forQthat is not significant. These findings are consistent with less efficient investment in PPE for the central members of horizontal industrial groups relative to their independent firm peers.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Firm Level Diversification
sec.p: Lins and Servaes (1999) find that diversified firms in Japan are valued at a discount relative to pure play firms only if they are in industrial groups. Their evidence suggests that the combination of firm‐level diversification and group membership is value decreasing. In this study, I base the estimate ofQfor conglomerate firms on the primary SIC for the firm. This proxy does not take into account the smaller divisions' growth opportunities. I conducted a test on a subset of single‐segment firms to discount the possibility that this proxy creates a measurement error systematically different between independent and group firms.13

The subset of firms is identified as single‐segment firms as discussed in Lins and Servaes (1999). The models in panel A oftable 6are separately estimated with only single‐segment firms. Panel D oftable 6reports the results. The coefficients for all variables are similar when comparing the results for single‐segment only regressions in panel D versus regressions that include single‐segment and conglomerate firms as reported in panel A. Some significance is lost for some of the coefficients. However, the coefficients are similar for each model, which suggests that the inclusion of conglomerate firms does not induce a systematic bias to the sample.

fn.p: I thank Karl Lins for generously providing conglomerate data that was used in Lins and Servaes (1999). Karl Lins identifies single‐segment firms as being single segment as of 1994.

Furthermore, the evidence shows a relation between the loss of value and the extent of misallocation.

To further investigate whether horizontal industrial groups' investment policies are inefficient and this inefficiency leads to lower valuations, I examined the deviation of predicted investment derived from model A, panel A, intable 6. The coefficients estimated from the independent firm model are applied to the explanatory variable values for each group firm. This provides an estimation of the predicted independent investment level for a group firm. The predicted investment is subtracted from the actual investment to calculate the deviation. Thus, a positive (negative) value indicates that the group firm invested more (less) than predicted, per the independent firm model.

Table 8reports the deviation (Dev) byQsubgroups. All firms are divided into thirds to create high, mid, and low subgroups forQ. The independent‐firm investment deviation is not statistically different from 0 across the subgroups, by construction, asQis a variable used in the regression model that generated the coefficients. There is some nonlinearity in the data to explain why the means for each subgroup ofQfor independent firms are not exactly 0.

Horizontal group members have significantly higher investment deviations in low‐Qindustries and significantly lower investment deviations in high‐Qindustries. This relation appears most pronounced for the presidential assembly members. The vertical‐group‐member investment deviation does not appear to follow a clear pattern.

When the median industryQis standardized, a positive (negative) value for standardizedQindicates a firm that is in an above‐ (below‐)averageQindustry. For the analyses that follow, I interact the standardized deviation of investment reported intable 8for each firm with its standardized growth opportunities creating a “relative investment deviation” (RID):
where:
STD(variable) = Standardized variable with a normal distribution,
Deviation (Dev) = residual for each firm using the coefficients estimated from model A, panel A intable 6,
Median industryQ= Median industry M/B for most specific SIC designation with at least five firms.

The standardized deviations interacted with standardizedQallows us to observe the distance away from predicted investment relative to the growth opportunities available to the firm. Standardizing each variable allows both variables to carry the same weight. This provides for a straightforward interpretation of the results. Positive values for RID reflect either high‐Qfirms that invest more than predicted or low‐Qfirms that invest less than predicted. Negative values for RID reflect firms that invest more (less) than the model predicts given their relatively low‐ (high‐)growth opportunities.

This measure is similar to Rajan et al.s' (2000) relative value added by allocation. Instead of measuring reallocation of capital within a conglomerate, as in the case of Rajan et al., here, we are interested in observing the reallocation of capital on a firm‐by‐firm basis across the economy. Rajan et al.'s measure of relative value added by allocation aggregates the interactions of relativeQ(Qof segment minus averageQof the conglomerate) and the differences in investment for each division relative to the investment level of single‐segment peers for each conglomerate firm. In contrast, RID measures the investment efficiency of each member of the industrial group. This is useful, as we can compare this to market values for each member of the internal capital market, which studies of conglomerates are unable to do.

Table 9provides the univariate statistics for RID for group firms. Presidential assembly firms and vertical core firms are reported as separate subsamples. By construction, independent firms have a mean value of 0 for RID and are unreported.14The results oftable 9are a direct reflection of the results in panel A oftable 6. In model B, horizontal group members have a near 0 coefficient forQand in model D presidential assembly members have a significantly negative coefficient forQrelative to the significantly positive coefficient for independent firms in model A. These coefficients are reflected in the significantly negative values for RID horizontal firms and even lower values of RID for presidential assembly members.

Table 10further explores horizontal‐firm investment by investigating the relation between the proxy for efficient investment, RID, and value in multivariate models. If deviations from the investment policy of independent firms reduce value, excess value is positively related to RID for the subset of group firms that have negative values of RID. It is less clear what the relation between RID and excess value is for the subset of group firms with positive values for RID, since it is not obvious whether independent firms, in the aggregate, are investing optimally.

In the first model, RID has a significantly positive relation to excess value. The last two models divide the sample into positive and negative values of RID. If independent firms invest more efficiently than horizontal‐group members, it seems logical that this measure is positively related to value as long as RID< 0. Whether the relation remains positive beyond this reflects whether the independent‐firm model represents optimal investment. The coefficient for RID for the RID< 0 subset is significant with ap‐value of 0.022. This suggests that horizontal firms can increase their value by utilizing an investment policy more similar to that of independent firms. The coefficient is positive for the RID > 0 subset but statistically insignificant.
Based on the findings intables 8,9and10, the observed investment policies for presidential assembly members are associated with reduced values.

fn.p: Due to some nonlinearity in the data, the mean RID for independent firms is −0.004, which has at‐statistic (p‐value) of −0.092 (0.926) relative to 0.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study provides evidence consistent with presidential assembly members losing value as a direct result of capital reallocation in horizontal industrial groups. An alternative explanation for some of the results presented in this study is that they are due to incorrectly specified independent variables. It is plausible that operating cash flow is highly correlated with growth opportunities. It is also reasonable that, in these models, the proxies ofQdo not completely capture the influence of growth opportunities in these models. Thus, the influence of growth opportunities could be partially reflected in the coefficient for operating cash flow.

This alternative explanation seems unlikely. First, two separate proxies for growth opportunities are used, obtaining similar results. This study avoids Chevalier's critique of using median industryQby also including a firm‐specific measure ofQ. The results are generally consistent using either proxy, suggesting that Chevalier's critique is not overly important in this setting. Second,table 6shows that, for a subset of horizontal‐group members, there is a negative relation between investment and a proxy forQ. An imperfect proxy for growth opportunities cannot explain the negative coefficient. Moreover, using a measure for investment efficiency based on the deviation from independent‐firm investment provides evidence that valuations are lower for these firms, which have a significantly lower relation between investment and industry growth opportunities. On balance, therefore, the evidence seems more consistent with the inefficient allocation hypothesis.

A limitation of this study is that it covers a period of economic malaise in Japan. It is not clear if these results are applicable beyond this particular time period. A possible interpretation of these results is that they reflect capital transfers that allow financially distressed firms to continue operations and avoid layoffs. This interpretation is consistent with the stronger results for asset growth relative to ΔPPE. Capital flows intended to aid financially distressed firms might more likely be reflected in current assets than in fixed assets. The evidence in panel B oftable 4and intable 6suggesting that industrial groups give low‐Qindustries priority for capital allocation are consistent with capital transfers to distressed firms.

Previous studies hypothesize and find evidence of a lower cost of capital for distressed group firms in Japan.15The time period in this study, arguably, has a greater overlap of firms that are both economically and financially distressed than previous studies. The evidence presented intables 7and10suggest that a cost is borne by the members of the presidential assembly of transferring capital to firms in less‐valuable industries, which suggests that the capital is not being used in positive net‐present‐value projects.

Finally, the results also show that both horizontal and vertical groups actively reallocate capital but in different ways. The results for horizontal groups are more evident, but the results are ambiguous on whether investment patterns are more or less efficient for vertical‐group members relative to independent firms. Previous authors, such as Shin and Stulz (1998) and Rajan et al. (2000), generally find that increased diversification leads to less‐efficient investment patterns. The evidence presented here complements these findings, in that it suggests that internal capital markets in the relatively more unrelated horizontal‐group firms are less effective than in the relatively more related vertical‐group firms.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Previous studies on industrial groups have provided evidence of reallocation of capital and, in some cases, increased investment efficiency in developing economies. This study also finds evidence consistent with reallocation but the evidence suggests that, in Japan, the reallocation of capital in industrial groups decreases investment efficiency, resulting in lower valuations. Moreover, the inefficient investment pattern appears to be most evident in the central members of the industrial groups.

The purpose of industrial groups in economies with developed financial markets, such as modern Japan, is not clear. The evidence presented in this study does not show why the industrial group structure remains a feature of the Japanese economy. Perhaps, industrial groups continue to exist not because of their economic value but due to legal and social complexities involved in dismantling the groups. This study cannot fully dismiss the view that the industrial groups are value increasing for some types of firms. However, I find a negative relation between the relative deviation of group‐firm investment to independent firms and excess value.

A caveat to this study is that it provides ex post evidence of reallocation of capital and the efficiency of that reallocation. It does not provide ex ante evidence of how groups reallocate capital. Keiretsus utilize complicated blends of financial and product contracts. An interesting area for further research would be to provide evidence on how keiretsus use these contracts to allow industrial groups to reallocate capital.
